Epic:Theory and History of a Literary Genre
Epic:Theory and History of a Literary Genre

The course will first present a reflection on the nature of epic, based on Aristotle’s theory of literary genres and its comments by the classical poetics (Boileau) and the Romanticists (Leopardi, Hugo). It will then follow the history of the genre from Gilgamesh to the Romantic epic, concentrating on some of the important works of World Literature.These examples will show the different forms and evolutions of the genre, from Homer’s Iliad and Odyssey to Hugo’s Legend of Centuries, across the Medieval “Song of Heroic Deeds” (Song of Roland), Dante’s Divine Comedy, Ariosto’s Orlando furioso, Tasso’s Jerusalem Delivered, Milton’s Lost Paradise.Through these examples, we will examine the general characters and their symmetries (the female archetypes like the warrior or the witch, the male hero in love or the traitor), the general structure of the plot and the transformation of epic from a heroic genre to a parody, and then to a praise of the nation.
The Artist Novel in Europe from Romanticism to Modernity
The Artist Novel in Europe from Romanticism to Modernity

This course will examine the birth and development of a literary genre in Europe, the “Artist Novel”. It will show how the genre takes its origin from another genre, the Bildungsroman, and develop another idea of art in its relationship to life. Of course, Heinse’s Ardinghello (1787) is known to be the first example of the genre, but German Romanticists like Tieck (Sternbald, 1798) and Novalis (Heinrich von Ofterdingen, 1802) are the first answers to Goethe’s Bildungsroman Wilhelm Meister.Novalis will be the starting point of the course. Then, with Balzac’s Unkwnow Masterpiece (1831) and Poe’s Oval Portrait (1842), we will examine the other side of the Romantic Artist Novel and the relationship it suggests between artistic creation and death. The course will then present the development of the genre in the Realist Novel (George Sand’s Consuelo, 1843; Zola’s The Work, 1886) and also its symbolist form (Oscar Wilde’s Picture of Dorian Gray, 1890). It will then show the dialog of the Modernity with Romanticism (Somerset Maugham, The Moon and Sixpence, 1919; Virginia Woolf, To the Lighthouse, 1927).The conclusion will point out the way the Artist Novel introduces in fiction a critical discourse. In doing so, it rejects the traditional distinction between creation and criticism, between imagination and reason.
Legal Issues Posed by Media Coverage of Celebrities
Legal Issues Posed by Media Coverage of Celebrities

Around the globe an increasing amount of media coverage focuses on athletes, actors, singers and “personalities” who thrive on public attention yet want to control the information conveyed about them. News outlets that publish celebrity journalism have even gained some respect for breaking major stories later picked up by more mainstream media.This course explores how American courts have handled legal disputes concerning media coverage of the public activities and private lives of celebrities and what rules media organizations follow to ensure they don’t get into legal trouble. Topics to be discussed include defamation, invasion of privacy and copyright infringement illustrated with examples of how some of the world’s most famous people have ended up in conflict with the journalists who cover them.

This course explores the wide variety of student media operations that exist at educational institutions in the U.S. and around the world and how journalism educators seek to better prepare the next generation of professional journalists in the classroom and the newsroom.

Focusing on The Anthropocene, this class will help students to develop a broad understanding of literary responses to environmental issues . The debates surrounding the term “Anthropocene” are central to the course. Students will investigate, interrogate, and explore these key concepts and, in so doing, will learn about the range and utility of ecocriticism. Students will be encouraged to read, to do as much research, and to educate themselves outside of the required readings as much as they possibly can. Internet searches of the anthropocence will yield an enormous amount of material, and students are encouraged to think and to question from an informed perspective. Student will gain some practical knowledge about ecomedia. One of the main questions we will be pursuing is about how the literature of the past has had and continues to have profound effects on the world and why it is therefore an extremely important area of study in this age of increasing change. With this in mind, I will encourage students to engage with contemporary materials as much as possible. The primary focus in this course will be on Anthropocene representations of food.- Bacigalupi, Paolo. The Windup Girl-Ozeki, Ruth. My Year of Meats-there will also be several scholarly articles assigned for the students to readStudents will be evaluated on the basis of daily writing assignments, quizzes, and a final exam.
